column4: hi all, i have a network consisting entirely of ubuntu server machines and would like to be able to talk to them on the lan using hostnames instead of IPs could anybody point me to some docs or howtos on that?
if they are all static ip's you could edit the hosts file on each one. thats teh simpilist way.
that's exactly the approach i wanted to avoid
then you need to look into setting up a dns/bind server.. id rather edit hosts file.
how big a network anyway?
4 machines
hosts file is probably easiest, but it's a testbed and configuration is still quite fluid
they all have static IPs but i'd rather have one place to change name resolution rather than have to go through 4 hosts files
you can sync the hosts file  with scp and a script.
or other ways...
how often are these things going to be changeing? You could always make up a script that scans the network and gets the hostnames :)
maybe on a weekly basis for now
how would i go about scanning the network and getting hostnames?
i basically can use 'findsmb' and get a hosts file (with a little editing) but all my machines have samba going.
smb is a no-go here
no use for it in my case, i'm setting up a linux only thing, not even GUIs
sounds like you need to learn some more advanced topics then. :)
problem is a dns would be total overkill for 4 machines
if testing goes well i might deploy on hundred of VMs and dozens of physical hosts where a dns server would be reasonable
llutz-n: thanks for the info on dnsmasq, just got a chance to set it up and it works like a charm
is right, python is a language that will return your investment in time and effort tenfold, it's just not a language to do kernel stuff in
